'''Ernie Hawkins''' (born '''Ernest Leroy Hawkins''', 1947, [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]]) is an [[United States|American]] acoustic [[blues]] [[guitar]] player, singer, recording artist, and educator, who has a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in [[Phenomenology (psychology)|phenomenological psychology]].

Hawkins, like [[Stefan Grossman]] and [[Roy Book Binder]], studied with blues legend [[Reverend Gary Davis]]<ref name="Chang">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p452049/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography: Ernie Hawkins|last=Chang|first=Ken|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=31 July 2010}}</ref> in [[New York City]] in 1965 and 1966.  Over the years, Hawkins learned a variety of styles, including [[Piedmont blues]], [[Delta blues]], [[country blues]], [[ragtime]], and [[gospel music|gospel]].  In 1969, Hawkins moved back  to his hometown of Pittsburgh, and enrolled at the [[University of Pittsburgh]], achieving a degree in [[philosophy]].  In 1973, Hawkins moved to [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] for graduate school and earned a Ph.D. in phenomenological psychology at the [[University of Dallas]], however, he remained active in music, and was able to perform with [[Mance Lipscomb]], [[Robert Pete Williams]], [[Fred McDowell]], and Robert "Nyles" Jones. In 1978, Hawkins decided to put aside his psychology career and become a full-time musician.  In the mid 1980s, Hawkins returned to Pittsburgh, and for the next ten years played [[lead guitar]] with the local [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] act Gary Belloma and the Blues Bombers.  Over the years, Hawkins has played with blues musicians such as [[Son House]], Mance Lipscomb, Fred McDowell, [[Jim Brewer (blues musician)|Jim Brewer]], Reverend Gary Davis and  others, and has been featured in ''[[Sing Out!]]'', ''Fingerstyle Guitar'', ''[[Dirty Linen]]'', ''[[Acoustic Guitar (magazine)|Acoustic Guitar]]'', ''Blues Revue'' and ''[[Vintage Guitar]]'' magazines. He has appeared on "[[A Prairie Home Companion]]", "[[Mountain Stage]]", "[[WoodSongs Old-Time Radio Hour]]" and [[XM Satellite Radio]].

Hawkins appeared on [[Maria Muldaur]]'s [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] and [[Blues Music Award]] nominated album ''Richland Woman Blues'' (2001), and was the guitarist for the national support tour.  He lives in Pittsburgh, and continues to perform, record, teach, and advocate blues music.
